current_fact.fact_text: In AD 41, after the assassination of the emperor Caligula, the Praetorian Guard reportedly found his uncle Claudius hiding behind a curtain and unexpectedly proclaimed him Roman emperor. Considered weak and awkward, Claudius would go on to become a capable ruler who expanded the empire and reformed its bureaucracy.

episode.title: Sedna FM #06 - Alters of an Ego
episode.description: What if you could step outside yourself and become someone freer, bolder, or completely unexpected? Exploring the artistry of musicians who craft alter-egos and parallel realities to experiment with new dimensions of their identity. It's not about hiding who they are — it's about expanding who they can be.
songs: The Fireman - Strawberries Oceans Ships Forest

current_fact.match_reason: Claudius’s sudden transformation from overlooked outsider to emperor mirrors the alter-ego theme—someone underestimated stepping into a powerful, unexpected role, much like artists reinventing themselves.

queue.fact_text: On this day in 1961, a U.S. B-52 bomber broke apart over Goldsboro, North Carolina, dropping two hydrogen bombs—one of which came perilously close to detonating, saved by a single safety switch that failed to flip. The incident, long kept partially secret, is one of the closest known near-misses to a nuclear catastrophe on American soil.

episode.title: Sedna FM #01 - November Bomb
episode.description: The first Family & Friends radio episode from Yasmin Sarbaoui and Gaia Parolini. Where it all began — a life soundtrack that launched Sedna FM into the universe. Raw, heartfelt, and full of the energy that defines everything that followed.
songs: Canserbero - De la vida como pelicula, tragedia, comedia y ficcion

queue.match_reason: A literal near-explosion of nuclear bombs pairs with an episode titled "November Bomb"—both evoke high stakes, explosions (real or metaphorical), and pivotal moments that change the course of a story.

queue.fact_text: In 1942, Allied aircraft bombed Bangkok, then under Japanese control, pushing Thailand to formally declare war on both the United States and the United Kingdom. The raids marked the arrival of the global conflict deep into Southeast Asia's urban centers and reshaped Thailand’s wartime diplomacy.

episode.title: Morning Drops #35 - Thailand
episode.description: Recorded in Koh Samui, Thailand, where Yasmin and her friend Patricia spent more than two intense weeks training Muay Thai and Western boxing. Between sweat, rhythm, and sea breeze, they share reflections on discipline, friendship, and the beauty of movement - with a soundtrack that connects Thai sounds to the flow of daily practice.
songs: Burna Boy - Cheat on Me (feat. Dave)

queue.match_reason: An episode rooted in contemporary Thailand counterbalances a wartime bombing of Bangkok, offering a modern, human-scale soundtrack to a place once caught in global conflict.

queue.fact_text: On this day in 914, the Fatimid Caliphate launched its first invasion of Egypt, sending forces across the desert to challenge the Abbasid Caliphate’s control of the Nile. Though ultimately unsuccessful, the campaign foreshadowed the Fatimids’ eventual conquest of Egypt and the founding of Cairo decades later.

episode.title: Morning Drops #02 - Waves of the Maghreb
episode.description: Oriental vibes guided by Yasmin. Discovering curious facts about the Maghreb, together with its fascinating music! A wonderful trip with a selection of songs from North Africa.
songs: Nass El Ghiwane - El Madi Fate

queue.match_reason: A North African Shi'a dynasty pushing toward Egypt fits naturally with an episode steeped in Maghreb sounds, tying medieval political tides to the enduring cultural waves of the region.

queue.fact_text: In 1966, Air India Flight 101 crashed into Mont Blanc in the Alps, killing all 117 people on board after a navigation error in bad weather. The mountain already held wreckage from a previous Air India crash, and decades later fragments, documents, and even jewels from the flights still occasionally emerge from the glacier ice.

episode.title: Morning Drops #22 - Sicilians On The Dolomites
episode.description: Hosted by Yasmin, a musical journey inspired by the mountains. Joined by two special guests, exploring the tracks they've chosen, hearing the stories behind their picks, and discovering the personal memories each song brings to life — a blend of music, voices, and landscapes you can hear.
songs: Florian Pellissier Quintet - Coup de foudre à Thessalonique
Lucio Dalla & Francesco De Gregori - Ma come fanno i marinai

queue.match_reason: A tragic aviation accident in the high Alps aligns with a mountain-themed episode; both evoke the drama and mystery of peaks, where clouds hide routes and stories emerge slowly from ice and memory.

queue.fact_text: On this day in 1918, revolutionary Russia officially adopted the Gregorian calendar, jumping from January 31 straight to February 14. Overnight, the country "lost" 13 days, aligning itself with Western timekeeping and adding an odd temporal twist to diaries and anniversaries from that year.

episode.title: Morning Drops #27 - Nomophobia
episode.description: Yasmin reflects on what happened when she recently lost her phone and why it felt freeing. A dive into the psychology of our relationship with smartphones: from nomophobia (the fear of being without a phone), to digital burnout and cognitive overload, to the surprising benefits of boredom and the brain's default mode network. An invitation to rethink how we connect and disconnect.

queue.match_reason: A nation abruptly changing its calendar mirrors a radical reset in how we structure time and connection—akin to putting the phone down and recalibrating our relationship to days, devices, and rhythms.

queue.fact_text: In 1915, during World War I, British and German battlecruisers clashed in the North Sea at the Battle of Dogger Bank. The engagement showcased both the power and vulnerability of modern steel navies, with long-range gunnery, miscommunications, and a dramatic magazine explosion shaping the outcome.

episode.title: Morning Drops #31 - Sailing With Germans
episode.description: From the deck of a sailing boat, hosted by Yasmin and her special guests. A week at sea with six Germans, each with their own stories, songs, and ways of moving through the waves. From shared meals to unexpected laughter, from quiet resilience to sun-soaked joy — a collection of voices and tracks that reflect what it means to journey together.
songs: Ben Howard - Keep Your Head Up

queue.match_reason: A naval battle in the North Sea involving British and German ships meets an episode literally set on a boat with German companions—transforming the idea of contested waters into a peaceful, shared voyage.

queue.fact_text: On this day in 2009, Cyclone Klaus swept into southwestern Europe, battering France and Spain with hurricane-force winds. The storm uprooted forests, cut power to millions, and disrupted transport, reminding temperate Europe that the atmosphere can turn suddenly wild.

episode.title: Morning Drops #14 - Slow Planet
episode.description: A pause. A quiet return to slower rhythms, sparked by a live set under the summer sky. A moment to breathe and settle into the week.

queue.match_reason: After a story of violent winds and disruption, a "Slow Planet" soundscape offers the opposite: calm atmospheric textures, as if the air has finally settled and the world can exhale again.

queue.fact_text: In 1935, the Gottfried Krueger Brewing Company introduced the first commercially successful canned beer in the United States. Early customers were so enthusiastic about the lighter, unbreakable cans that rival breweries rushed to follow, reshaping not just beer culture but packaging, recycling, and how people drink on the go.

episode.title: Sedna FM #05 - On The Go - Zero Zero
episode.description: An energetic mix for when you're on the move. Zero Zero captures that feeling of starting fresh, moving forward, and embracing the journey. Perfect for travel, walks, or just getting things done.
songs: Grace Jones - Pull up to the bumper
Easy star all star - Soul love
James Brown - Talking loud and saying nothing (remix)

queue.match_reason: Canned beer is literally designed for being "on the go", pairing neatly with a travel-ready, energetic mix that celebrates movement and fresh starts—like cracking open a cold one for the journey.

queue.fact_text: On this day in 1651, Spanish colonial authorities and Mapuche leaders met at the Parliament of Boroa in Chile, attempting once again to negotiate peace in the long-running Arauco War. These parliaments were rare moments where indigenous and colonial powers sat face to face, blending diplomacy, ritual, and fragile compromise.

episode.title: Morning Drops #16 - The Sound of Tuareg
episode.description: A journey into the sound of the Tuareg: from traditional chants and desert rituals to the electrified rhythms of exile and resistance. Music shaped by sand, memory, and survival.

queue.match_reason: An indigenous Mapuche–Spanish parliament about land and resistance resonates with Tuareg desert blues—both speak to colonization, negotiation, and the enduring voice of indigenous cultures under pressure.

queue.fact_text: In 2003, the United States Department of Homeland Security officially began operating, consolidating 22 federal agencies into a vast bureaucracy focused on preventing and responding to terrorism and disasters. Its creation marked a profound reorganization of how one country thinks about borders, safety, and surveillance.

episode.title: Morning Drops #13 - Demystifying Reggaeton
episode.description: Yasmin takes us on a journey through the real story of reggaeton — from its roots in Panama and Puerto Rico to its global evolution. Exploring the genre's history, influences, and cultural impact.
songs: Renato - Chica de los Ojos Café
B. F. Yaviah - Si Tu Quieres Fumar

queue.match_reason: While a government builds walls and security apparatuses, reggaeton—born from marginalized communities across borders—slips through and goes global, making an interesting counterpoint between control and cultural flow.

queue.fact_text: On this day in 1972, Shoichi Yokoi, a Japanese sergeant who had been hiding in the jungles of Guam since World War II, was finally discovered by local hunters. Unaware the war had ended decades earlier, he survived in a handmade underground shelter, becoming a symbol of endurance, loyalty, and isolation.

episode.title: Morning Drops #33 - Immerse
episode.description: An analogy between diving, one of Gaia's great passions, and the act of immersing in life itself. A reflection on what happens when we go below the surface: when we let ourselves be fully present. From moments of calm suspension to warm, rhythmic flow, the selection moves like water — fluid, organic, and alive. An invitation to slow down, listen deeper, and float.
songs: Pino D'Angiò - Un Po' d'Uva e un Liquore

queue.match_reason: Yokoi’s decades-long immersion in the jungle is an extreme, haunting version of going "below the surface"; pairing it with a fluid, reflective episode reframes isolation as deep, if painful, presence.

queue.fact_text: In 1968, during the Vietnam War, the 1st Australian Task Force launched Operation Coburg, moving into contested territory near Biên Hòa and Long Bình. The operation aimed to disrupt attacks around major allied bases as the broader Tet Offensive loomed on the horizon.

episode.title: Morning Drops #04 - Bars With Balls
episode.description: Yasmin dives into Women's Day through the voices of four incredible female rappers. Morning fire from the magic planet of Sedna FM — move your hands up and down with us. Hip hop culture through a feminine lens.
songs: Little Simz - Point and Kill (feat. Obongjayar)

queue.match_reason: A complex, brutal conflict like Vietnam invites voices that confront power and injustice; the fierce, politically aware energy of women in hip hop provides a modern, resistant soundtrack to thinking about war.

queue.fact_text: On this day in 1943, Franklin D. Roosevelt and Winston Churchill concluded the Casablanca Conference, where they agreed on the principle of "unconditional surrender" of the Axis powers. Behind the iconic photo ops, the meeting involved intricate debates over strategy, timing, and the future map of the world.

episode.title: Morning Drops #32 - A Weekend In London
episode.description: Recorded in London, marking a weekend reunion between Gaia and Yasmin. A selection inspired by London's energy, seen through the eyes of two inseparable friends — music from concerts, club nights, and long walks across town. Four tracks to ease you into the week at the right pace.
songs: Jimmy Castor Bunch - It's Just Begun
The Asphodells - Late Flowering Lust (Phil Kieran Remix)

queue.match_reason: The conference hinged on British–American coordination; pairing it with a London-centered episode highlights the city as a modern stage where allied histories, politics, and cultures still intersect and remix.

queue.fact_text: On this day in 2009, windstorm Klaus slammed into Bordeaux and much of southwestern Europe, snapping power lines and flattening forests. France’s famed wine country briefly became a landscape of toppled trees and darkened towns, showing how quickly climate and weather can rewrite even the most carefully cultivated terroir.

episode.title: Morning Drops #27 - Endless Summer
episode.description: Recorded from Fano, a quiet town on the Adriatic coast where summer stretches long and slow. Between swims, simple meals, and time with family, Gaia reflects on the kind of music that helps us return to ourselves. Through different shades of jazz — from minimal and meditative to warm and rhythmic — an invitation to slip into that endless summer feeling.

queue.match_reason: A violent windstorm cutting through a wine region contrasts with the gentle, sunlit mood of "Endless Summer"—a reminder of how precarious calm climates and leisurely landscapes really are.

queue.fact_text: In 1935, Krueger's canned beer roll-out included a simple taste test: 2,000 drinkers received free cans, and 91% gave them a thumbs-up. That small experiment in user feedback helped convince a whole industry to embrace metal packaging over glass.

episode.title: Morning Drops #41 - Sedna's friends: Marina
episode.description:
Today's Morning Drops episode feels like an easy coffee with someone you instantly get along with. It also introduces Sedna's Friends, a new sub-format where friends are invited to drink coffee and share the music they love.

Gaia invites her friend Marina, artist and aspiring singer, to share music, small thoughts, and that comfortable kind of conversation between good friends. They met by chance at a party and connected right away through music, creativity, and a healthy dose of sarcasm.

This episode sounds exactly like that: relaxed, honest, and a bit spontaneous. Press play, get comfortable, and enjoy the listen.

queue.match_reason: Sharing early canned beer with ordinary people to see what they think echoes the cozy, conversational feel of an episode built around friends sharing tastes, stories, and small experiments in what feels good.

queue.fact_text: When Hiten launched in 1990, one of its clever tricks was releasing a small daughter probe, Hagoromo, toward the Moon. Although Hagoromo’s transmitter failed, Hiten still used radio tracking to confirm it successfully entered lunar orbit—an example of salvaging science from unexpected failure.

episode.title: Morning Drops #19 - Wabi Sabi
episode.description: Wabi-sabi is a story about a handmade mug, a small mistake, and the idea that imperfection can be something to keep—not correct. In this Morning Drop, Gaia shares a moment that didn’t go to plan, and four tracks that echo the same spirit: rough takes, studio accidents, lo-fi textures, and quiet surprises. A soft, thoughtful selection moving between warm electronics, classic riffs, and raw edges.A reminder that not everything needs to be polished. Sometimes, it’s better that way.

queue.match_reason: Hagoromo’s failed transmitter yet successful orbit is orbital wabi-sabi—a flawed mission that still produced beauty and data, aligning with an episode celebrating imperfect outcomes and quiet surprises.

queue.fact_text: Voyager 2’s 1986 flyby of Uranus revealed that the planet’s magnetic field is wildly tilted and offset from its center, unlike Earth’s relatively neat dipole. This lopsided magnetosphere may create bizarre, shifting auroras and seasons—magnetic weather on a planetary scale.

episode.title: Morning Drops #31 - A Trip-Hop Journey
episode.description: Hosted by friend Lorenzo, a journey through the roots and evolution of trip-hop. From Bristol's early experiments with Massive Attack and Tricky, to DJ Shadow's cinematic sampling in California, and Thievery Corporation's global downtempo grooves in Washington D.C. — exploring how this genre blurred boundaries and reshaped electronic music.
songs: Tricky - Hell Is Round the Corner
DJ Shadow - Midnight in a Perfect World

queue.match_reason: Uranus’s tilted, off-center magnetic field is a cosmic analog to trip-hop’s skewed, boundary-blurring sound—familiar physics and beats, rearranged into something strangely beautiful and atmospheric.

published.fact_text: In 1990, Japan launched Hiten, its first lunar probe and the first robotic mission to the Moon by any country other than the United States or the Soviet Union. Hiten pioneered new orbital techniques, including aerobraking and a clever use of gravity assists, helping to usher in a new era of international lunar exploration.

episode.title: Morning Drops #03 - Space Shift
episode.description: Gaia invites you to shift your mindset with a simple yet powerful reflection: What if we saw emptiness not as a void but as space to create? An energising and feel-good selection of tracks, the perfect way to ease into your day and set the tone for the week ahead.
songs: Willy J Healey - Woke Up Smiling
The Strokes - You Only Live Once

published.match_reason: A pioneering lunar mission fits the "Space Shift" theme of turning emptiness into creative space, and the upbeat electronic edge mirrors the bold step of entering a new era of moon exploration.

published.fact_text: On this day in 1986, Voyager 2 made its closest approach to Uranus, becoming the first—and so far only—spacecraft to visit the ice giant up close. The flyby revealed 11 new moons, strange dark rings, and an unexpectedly tilted magnetic field, transforming Uranus from a pale dot into a richly complex world.

episode.title: Evening Flows #01 - Yasmin - Crescendo in the Medina
episode.description: The first Evening Flow episode comes from Yasmin. It starts deep in the medina, slow, mysterious, textured, and grows into a liberating dance across sub-Saharan landscapes. A journey through ambient soundscapes, Arabic melodies, Afro-Latin rhythms, and funky highlife grooves.
songs: David Visan & Carlos Campos - Crystal Heart
Evan Mars - Ya Zareef Al Tool
Dele Sosimi & Medlar - You No Fit Touch Am (Medlar Remix)

published.match_reason: Voyager 2’s passage through the outer solar system echoes the episode’s slow, mysterious build into expansive, liberating grooves—like drifting past a cold, distant world into a cosmic dance.

published.fact_text: In 1978, the Soviet satellite Kosmos 954, powered by a nuclear reactor, broke apart in Earth's atmosphere and scattered radioactive debris across Canada's Northwest Territories. The resulting recovery effort, code-named Operation Morning Light, was one of the earliest large-scale attempts to track and clean up space nuclear contamination on the ground.

episode.title: Morning Drops #05 - Electric Shock
episode.description: An energizing episode with electrifying sounds to wake you up and get you moving. High energy tracks that deliver a jolt of musical electricity to start your day.

published.match_reason: A nuclear-powered satellite burning up over Earth is a literal "electric shock" from space, matching the episode’s high-voltage rock energy and its sense of dangerous, uncontrolled power.

published.fact_text: On this day in 1848, carpenter James W. Marshall noticed shiny flakes in a California millrace and realized they were gold, sparking the California Gold Rush. Within a year, people from around the world were streaming into the region, reshaping ecosystems, economies, and cultures in a frantic search for glittering metal.

episode.title: Morning Drops #24 - The Rise Of Afrobeat
episode.description: An exploration of the rise of Afrobeat, tracing its roots and evolution as a genre that blends African rhythms with jazz, funk, and highlife. A celebration of the infectious energy and cultural significance of this influential musical movement.

published.match_reason: The frenzy and migration of the Gold Rush parallel the explosive rise of Afrobeat—both are about resource rushes, one for gold and one for rhythm, drawing people across continents into a new cultural landscape.

published.fact_text: In 1946, the very first resolution of the United Nations General Assembly created the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission. In the shadow of Hiroshima and Nagasaki, this body was tasked with figuring out how humanity might control atomic energy and prevent nuclear weapons from defining the future.

episode.title: Morning Drops #42 - The Joy Of Learning
episode.description:
Hosted by Yasmin, this Morning Drop explores learning as a lifelong process, focusing on persistence, repetition, and the emotional landscape that comes with challenging oneself over time.

Through personal stories and scientific insights, the episode looks at how learning reshapes the brain, generates joy through effort, and why progress often arrives after confusion and frustration. It reflects on the so-called delayed pleasure effect, the role of dopamine in motivation, and how curiosity and learning support long-term wellbeing.

The episode also questions our cultural relationship with failure and invites a softer, more realistic approach to learning, one that accepts mistakes as part of growth and sees persistence as a quiet form of strength.

Mood: reflective, grounded, quietly hopeful
Music genre: alternative rock, hip hop, electronic, neo-soul, drill

A space to listen slowly and stay with the process.

published.match_reason: Creating a global commission to understand and regulate atomic energy is a massive collective learning project, resonating with an episode about persistence, scientific insight, and changing how we handle power and failure.

published.fact_text: On this day in 1939, the Chillán earthquake struck central Chile, becoming the deadliest quake in the country's history with around 28,000 lives lost. The disaster not only reshaped the city but also prompted major advances in Chilean seismology and building codes, influencing earthquake engineering worldwide.

episode.title: Morning Drops #45 - It Can't Rain Forever
episode.description:
In this first broadcast of 2026, Gaia returns from the vivid landscapes of Morocco to open a space for reflection. This episode navigates the delicate transition between closing a significant chapter and stepping into the new year. It explores the concept of constancy amidst change, celebrating the grounding force of friendship and the creative sanctuary that is Sedna FM.

The musical selection mirrors this journey, moving from the orchestral depth of changing seasons into the golden warmth of psychedelic soul. It recalls memories of Swiss mountains and unexpected downpours, reminding us that shared optimism can weather any storm.

Take a moment to breathe in the new morning and listen deeply.

Mood: Reflective, Warm, Transitional, Hopeful
Music genre: Classic Rock, Psychedelic Soul, Pop Rock, Soft Rock

published.match_reason: A devastating earthquake is a reminder that the ground itself can shift, tying into the episode’s reflections on weathering storms and finding constancy and hope after catastrophic change.
